`7From`6:`7 Volkare
`7Subj`6:`7 Heron Hall Rooms
Just for your perusal, and to see if you want to add in the rooms for Valk.
1st Floor:
`&The `#H`3eron `#H`3all`& Meeting Room`7 (public, Outer Street to South, Dining Room to East, Training Room to West, Second Floor Hallway to Up)

`7Broad windows at the front of the building let in a great deal of `#l`&ight`7, as well as providing a good view of the street outside and the `1Sau`!c`1y `!Wen`1c`1h`7 across it. There are several small clusters of `3wooden`7 chairs around low tables scattered about the room, apparently set up as places to talk business with the mercenaries of `#H`3eron `8Company`7. A stairway leads from the front of the building up to the second floor at the east side of the room, with another door beneath the stairs leading to the Dining Room. The lone doorway on the west side of the room leads to the Training Room.
`&The `#H`3eron `#H`3all`& Dining Room`7 (public, Meeting Room to West, Kitchens to North)

`7This long, low room has a series of `3d`8a`2r`8k `2w`8o`2o`8d`7 tables with benches running alongside. A few round `3tables`7 circled by chairs fill up the empty space along the west wall, and a wide `1f`!i`7r`1e`!p`7l`1a`!c`7e rests at the north end of the room, alongside a door to the kitchens. The door back to the Meeting Room lies on the west wall.
`&The `#H`3eron `#H`3all`& Kitchens`7 (public, Dining Room to South, Stables to North)

`7S`8t`&o`7n`8e`7 ovens and heavy `8i`7r`8o`7n stoves line this room, making it warm no matter what time of year it is. By the equipment, smells, and the small amount of food visible when the cooks aren't working, the fare made here tends towards good and solid, with little flare or fancy doings. The door to the south leads into the Dining Room, and another door on the north side of the room leads outside to the Stableyard.
`&The Stables of `#H`3eron `#H`3all`7 (public, Kitchen to South)

`7Behind the three-story building that serves as the headquarters of `#H`3eron `8Company`7 lies an open stableyard almost the same size. A large stable juts off from the main building like the arm of an 'L,' holding the horses of `#H`3eron `8Company`7 in small but comfortable stalls. One can often see small units of mercenaries drilling with pikes or spears in the open space between the stable and the barracks.
`&The `#H`3eron `#H`3all`& Training Room`7 (public, Meeting Room to East)

`7This room takes up the majority of the first floor of the building. A few `3wooden`7 pillars are scattered around to support the upper floors, but otherwise the room is completely open. `&C`3a`7n`&v`7a`&s`7 covers the floor, with `!r`1e`!d`7 circles painted on it, and racks of `3lathes`7 and other `&w`7e`&a`7p`&o`7n`&s`7 line the walls. There is a `1f`!i`7r`1e`!p`7l`1a`!c`7e along the west wall to take some of the chill off, but it seems to be rarely used, given how often there are mercenaries practicing their livelihood in the room. There is an ostentatiously large `&lo`7ok`8ing g`7la`&ss`7 along one wall, for practicing forms in front of. The door back to the Meeting Room is in the east wall.
2nd Floor:
`&The Second Floor Hallway`7 (public, Barracks to West, File Leader's Room to South, Volante's room to East, Telen's room to North, Meeting Room to Down, Third Floor Landing to Up)

`7This hallway connects the stairs at the front of the building that lead down to the first floor with the ones at the back of the building that lead up to the top floor. Several `3doors`7 on the west side of the hallway open out into a large barracks, while `3doors`7 on the east side of the hall lead to the individual rooms of the File Leaders. `&W`6i`7ndo`6w`&s`7 at either end of the hallway and `8la`1n`3t`#e`3r`1n`8s`7 between each of the doors keep the place bright day or night.
`&The `#H`3eron `#H`3all`& Barracks`7 (public, Second Floor Hallway to East)

`7This cavernous room is filled with double-stacked `3bunks`7, five to a row. There looks to be room for at least a hundred mercenaries to sleep in the room. `1F`!i`7r`1e`!p`7l`1a`!c`7e`1s`7 stand on the west and north ends of the room, and the southwest corner is curtained off by simple `3c`7anva`3s`7 sheets, providing some measure of privacy for the female members of `#H`3eron `8Company`7.
`&A File Leader's Room`7 (public, Second Floor Hallway to North)

`7This small but comfortable room is set aside for the use of one of `#H`3eron `8Company`7's File Leaders. It has a wardrobe and small weapons rack along one wall, a bed along another, and a writing `3desk`7 under a `&w`6i`7nd`6o`&w`7 along a third.
File Leader Denshanai's Room (private, Second Floor Hallway to West)
To be desced by Volante if she wants the room.
File Leader Kerraid's Room (private, Second Floor Hallway to South)
To be desced by Te
`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--

`7From`6:`7 Sadren
`7Subj`6:`7 Petitioner's Square
Before the Tower, directly before, is the Petitioner's Square.
It is where people come to petition Aes Sedai and the Amyrlin.
We have two choices. Either I can move the Plaza 1 s, and input
the petitioner's square where the plaza is, or you have to
make the room 9400 the petitioner's square, but that might mean changing
your teleporter.
Tell me what to do boss!
And also, I can't figure out how to see empty rooms in a zone.

`7Subj`6:`7 I crashed Builder Port.
`7CC`6: `7Duren Nicodemus
I don't know why it happened, but I was looking over the teleporter
rooms and I tried to make the room have no exits, so people would
actually use the teleporter.

saved. No big deal, but I wanted to let you know.

`7From`6:`7 Rissa
`7Subj`6:`7 Re: Balinor
I probably should have sent this to other people, but whatever.
Here are my thoughts regarding Maelyn and Balinor.

I personally would rather see AS and WD as a cohesive guild unit.  I think the two work far too closely, and are too inherently linked to operate as separate entities.  That's just my opinion, though, and clearly Balinor - who is the GL - feels otherwise.

I haven't seen him being rude or obnoxious about getting his guild revamped.  If anything, he's been more professional than I would have at first given him credit for.  I think he has a vision for warders that is just different than what we have all grown used to.  Change is scary sometimes and many many people (myself and Maelyn included) are highly resistant to it.  That doesn't necessarily mean that the changes he's making are bad.

I think Maelyn needs to talk to him first before asking us to make him stop.  The two of them -have- to be able to work together, and if the imms come down from on high and make Balinor stop doing what he feels is right for the guild to boost activity and standards, there will be nothing but discontent.  Unless and until we see him doing things that are blatantly against policy or that we can all agree is damaging to the overall functioning of the Tower, I don't see it as our place to stick our noses in.

Do I personally agree with Maelyn?  Yes.  I think Balinor should have left the guilds together and not segregated them.  Do I have any rational reason for that?  Not really: just status quo.  So far, it seems Balinor has brought a lot of vision and drive to the GLship - far more than I would have thought when he was promoted - and I don't really see any reason for US to step in and ask him to stop.  This may all change if/when Maelyn talks to him depending on his reactions to that conversation, but for now, that's pretty much where I'm at.

I don't want to see Maelyn upset because she really is a fantastic AS leader and is good for the guild as a whole, so normally I would be all about doing whatever it takes to make her happy with it, but right now, despite my personal agreement with her on Balinor's actions, I really don't see any way to step in with a clear conscience and force him to change his goals and plans for WD.
Hope that made sense.
Rissa

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Maelyn
`7Subj`6:`7 A few concerns
I'm not sure how to approach this topic, so forgive me if I seem to ramble a bit. I think
we each have some very different expectations and assumptions about our roles here, and
how best to approach them, and in some ways they seem to be at cross purposes, so I
thought it might be a good idea to get together and find out where we are
misunderstanding each other. First, let me try to explain what is bothering me. Again, I
apologize if I am rambling.
For many years the WD and AS guilds were separate entities, working together only in
the academic sense. There was a lot of friction between the groups and the GLs, and it
translated to a confusing atmosphere for the payers. To improve this, the Tower guild was
created, and the WD and AS guilds became subgroupings inside that larger umbrella. The
Tower sometimes had one GL, sometimes 2, and there have been times there have been
as many as 4 GLS. Most recently, the Tower had Melinda doing it on her own, then
Samir joined her, then I replaced Melinda, then I handled it by myself for a while.
Through all those changes we always worked very hard to make sure the guild functioned
as one cohesive whole. When more than one person was GL, normally one had
responsibility for one side and one had responsibility for the other, but that was more a
flexible guideline than a hard and fast rule. In practice, each of us had responsibility for
the guild as a whole. We talked regularly about what we were seeing and issues that had
come up, we'd discuss policies and how they needed to change (or remain in effect as the
case may be), if important decisions came up we would do our best to either discuss them
together before announcing them, or at least frame them in such a way as to say - this
may be subject to change once I've had a chance to speak to X, but for now I'd say
(whatever) if the player/Imm was pressing for an immediate reaction. For Samir and I,
the way we divided things was - he was the main go to person for WD, I was the main go
to person for AS, but either of us could do anything in the other's side if needed. We
were both listed as GLs on every subguild of the Tower, and had every right to do what
needed doing when the other was not around. To large extent this worked because of the
high level of trust and communication we had, but the concept was the same as the one he
and Melinda used, and that previous multiple GL periods had adopted.
After he left and I was the sole GL, the game was fairly slow, and I didn't think it was a
problem to handle things on my own. It still isn't, but as the player base started to
increase I began thinking a second GL would have several benefits. First, I am definitely
NOT an emote fighter and have no skills in teaching that portion of the syllabus. Having
someone designated for that job would be a great benefit. Second, as much as I do my
best to be available as much as I can, the truth is that since going back to school I have
had significant periods when it has been very hard to be here every day, or even every
week. School is winding down (I am due to finish in June) but that doesn't mean that
something else might not pop up to take its place. Having a backup for those times would
be good for the players.  And third, when a difficult issue comes up, it helps to have
someone that you can talk to about it, get a different perspective, and generally bounce
ideas off. Now, I  could find a player willing to be an IC MOI to take that part of the job,
and nothing says I can't talk to various Imms/players I have come to know and trust for
their opinions if I really needed to do that, and the world will not end if the guild is left
without me for a few days or a week, but the fact is, I thought it would be easier to see if I
could enlist the help of a second GL. That's where you came in. My expectations when
you were given the role was that we would have the same basic framework that Sam and
I had, with the understanding that it may not work as smoothly or seamlessly until we had
gotten to know each other's styles and built that level of trust. I expected a transition
period, but it seems to me, just  based on some of the things you have said and done since
becoming GL, and a few other things I have noticed, that you had a very different idea of
what your role would be. From my point of view, it seems you want the AS and WD
guilds to be separate entities, with the Tower being more a matter for conversational
convenience than anything else.
For instance, policies: You seem to feel we need WD policies that you write without my
input, AS policies that I write without your input, and a few Tower policies w
`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--

`7Subj`6:`7 The Stairwell.
I was talking with Maelyn about the stairwell, and the whole forty
flights is really time consuming to try and get up.
What I had in mind was removing most of them, and putting in
teleporters between the zones. The first, main floor, then
a teleporter, the novice halls, then a teleporter, etc etc
until you reach the top.
I didn't want to make any changes without consulting you though.

column7: Fwd: questions on darkfriends' role in a background

column1: `7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Telen
`7Subj`6:`7 questions on darkfriends' role in a background
`7CC`6: `7Shai'tan Lucardo
Hello.

There was a question on my background that Syrah said could pass, as it was, only if it was done by a darkfriend/Black Ajah.  So I went with that.  Syrah also noted that since my background included no details of the darkfriend involvement, that if Telen found a clearer memory, I should discuss the details with Maelyn.  It occurred to me that while that was true, I should note the Great Lord of the Dark for permission or advice before speaking with Maelyn.

While in the White Tower for about two years, Telen is angreal/ter'angreal damaged, told it cannot be healed after at least one attempt (which seemed like healing to him) and set out of the White Tower with gold.  I had assumed if a darkfriend did this, one of a few things could or should have happened.  First, if he was damaged, he'd be killed while still at the White Tower.  Second, he would be killed as he left or when he arrived home, southwest of Shol Arbola or in the city where he has relatives.  Since it would be nice if neither of these happened, either the pursuit met with misfortune, or was again delayed for some reason, either to distance a connection to the White Tower or because Telen did not remain in Shol Arbola but traveled with good speed to Caemlyn.

He has been in Caemlyn for several months now.  There was one crazy role-play when he first arrived where someone playing a NPC tried to kill him 'as ordered' but a darkfriend acting like that probably wouldn't have lasted very long serving Shadow.  The NPC was bound by a nearby channeler and turned over to the Queen's guard.  (Oocly, he was incredibly rude to the channeler and might have been removed from the game.)  Third, Telen may have been compelled or otherwise influenced before his release from the White Tower.  If he's going to be pursued and murdered sometime in the future, well, I don't need to know that.  If Shadow has a plausible scenario that allows the background and role-play so far (which includes only the incomplete memory as stated), that would be great.

The reason I would like to know this is that it has come up in role-play that there are new methods of healing at the White Tower.  Before I make something up, I would like to know what responsibility Shadow has for monitoring darkfriend involvement.  Does the Shadow have an opinion on whether Telen might be compelled to stay away? To be silent? Would the Black Ajah be aware of it if he returns and would she care? What other behavior might be instilled?
He is a latent channeler.  The reason for his stay in the White Tower was a Brown Ajah study on wolfkin.  He is not wolfkin, but there were two over the last century in his family.
Thank you for your time.

If Shadow has a plausible scenario that allows the background and role-play so far (which includes only the incomplete memory as stated), that would be great.

The reason I would like to know this is that it has come up in role-play that there are new methods of healing at the White Tower.  Before I make something up, I would like to know what responsibility Shadow has for monitoring darkfriend involvement.  Does the Shadow have an opinion on whether Telen might be compelled to stay away? To be silent? Would the Black Ajah be aware of it if he returns and would she care? What other behavior might be instilled?
He is a latent channeler.  The reason for his stay in the White Tower was a Brown Ajah study on wolfkin.  He is not wolfkin, but there were two over the last century in his family.
Thank you for your time.
`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Lila
`7Subj`6:`7 A question regarding Talents
Syrah,
I play a Recruit, soon to be Soldier of the Black Tower named Etheavin.
According to his background, he comes from a tradition of blacksmiths, and
is one himself. I am mailing you to ask if I could pursue the Talent of
Power Forging. I know that it is a Lost Talent, and I am not asking for
you to just give it to me. I am -wanting- to work for this ability, because
it gives me some really great RP opportunities to really flesh out my
character. It is my thought that, since the Black and White Towers are
working towards an alliance, bringing Etheavin to the White Tower to work
on this with an Aes Sedai would demonstrate a willingness towards cooperation
and allow me to pursue a goal that I don't believe has been explored yet
here on Tyme.
As I mentioned before, I am not wanting this to just be granted to me for
one reason or another. I am willing to put the time and effort into
rediscovering this Talent. If this is okay with you, Mail or Tell me, and
perhaps we can work out the requirements I would have to reach to discover
this Talent for myself.
Sincerely,
Lila/Etheavin.
P.S. It might be interesting to discover that Etheavin can only Power Forge
when Linked with an Aes Sedai. If you feel that Power Forging is too strong
for one person to have, this requirement of cooperation would be an interesting
twist to the Talent.

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Termiane
`7Subj`6:`7 News from Caemlyn
Master Lonaise,
I'm glad to hear that you're still well. I'm trying to convince Rienne to come out to
help pick up the pieces. I think it won't take much more to get her to join me. She's
betrothed to a Lord from Saldaea, and thinks to use that connection to bring Saldaea
and the other Borderlands into the fight against the Seanchan. Hopefully you will get
to meet her soon. I think that you and my Aunt will both enjoy speaking with her.
-Term.

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Sue
`7Subj`6:`7 Sue's Background
Sue was a troubled child, even without the stigma attached to his girly
name.  His parents had a very unhappy marriage childhood sweethearts who
found out only after marriage that they really didnt like each other.  His
mother, Amilie, was a seamstress, and his father, Meldan, a soldier.
Amilie tried to run a shop alone while her husband was out guarding things
or out on patrol, only adding to her bitterness that she was the bread-
winner of the family, income-wise, and she worked, at least in her opinion,
much harder than he did.  Meldan died in what was officially called a
training accident while Amilie was pregnant with their first child, and
when the boy was born, she named him after her mother, Susannah, or Sue
for short, mostly to spite the boys father, who always thought that men
should be manly, and wanted Amilie to give up her business so he could be
manly and support her, even if it meant they would live in much less
comfort.
Sue grew up with stories about his father that made him think he was a no-
good drunken lout, among other things.  His mother spoiled him as well, and
the young boy was used to getting what he wanted.  When he was old enough,
his mother decided he needed to learn a trade, like she did, so he could
support himself, and her, when she became too old to continue sewing.  She
found a blacksmith to take in her brat of a son, and had to actually PAY
the blacksmith to keep him on as an apprentice as the boy became gradually
more unruly.  He wasnt used to having to do work.  When he finally learned
enough to start making a bit of money off of his work, she kept whatever
profits were left to repay her for what she spent on his training, after
the Master Blacksmith that Sue was training under took his cut.
Going from a life of relative laziness and luxury to one of hard work for
no pay only made him resent his mother. He vowed to become the best damn
smith in the city, and once he was good enough, he would take his skills
and go elsewhere to practice his trade, so that his greedy mother got none
of HIS profits.
This was not to be, however, since the boy, as he grew up, started to
frequent the taverns with silver he squirreled away before his mother
could get her hands on it, and gained a bit of a reputation for starting
trouble when he got too drunk.
Whatever else he might be, Sue was not stupid, and he saw where his path
was starting to take him.  Deciding he needed to get out of his Mothers
house, and out from under her overbearing skirts, before he got into REAL
trouble, he started looking for a place of his own to live, despite his
relative youth.  He wasn't yet good enough, in his opinion, to open his
own shop and compete against other smiths like his former master, but he
knew that his skills were good enough to get by.  Wanting to ally with
people who would not only appreciate his simple but sturdy workmanship, but
would also give him some REAL power, he started to seek out one of the
Black-Coated men who wander the city, to see if they needed a decent
blacksmith.  He has no idea that he had the ability to learn to channel,
but he may find that out soon enough.

column7: RE My Application to the White Tower

column1: `7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Hanna
`7Subj`6:`7 RE My Application to the White Tower
`7CC`6: `7Maelyn Balinor

Hanna was the middle of 5 children born to Taldar and Moira Haldane.  Though at one point they could trace the family line back to some sort of minor noblility all that was left any family fortune was a small inn that they turned into a cafe while living upstairs in the former lodgings.  Early in her parents marriage the business was quite brisk though as the neighbourhood grew older many of the businesses relocated to be replaced with other business some times they were turned intop residences and in a fw cases they were left empty. The decrease in foot traffic as other areas became the new trendy hotspots meant that where once coin was plentiful is mostly dried up into a core of regulars that mostly formed those from the neighbourhood.

As a result by the time Hanna was born though the business was quite brisk and often times they all had to do without as money was often tight. Indeed though her parents would hardworking and dedicated they lacked the  innovation required to adjust to the changing clientele. As her mother gave birth to two more daughters the family funds were stretched thier fortunes did not improve till Hanna started to learn the trade.    Her zeal and earnest desire to help out the family lead her parents to teach her the trade as they did her older brothers unlike them however she seemed to have a knack for baking and cooking in general. This was more a result of Hanna's attention to detail and stubborn refusal to give up any task which she did not immediately master as much as it was her very real natural talent.

s her sisters grew older Hanna also helped take care of them more and more as her mother resumed her duties with the business. She would often take great pains to include them in everything she did despite them being younger and often what many would consider an annoyance. Kassandra the next youngest next to Hanna and was always frail and sickly desapite the constant ailements which at worst would leave her bed ridden her parents never took her to the tower and would broke no disccusion of it. Her father was rather strict often going over board which did lead to frequent fights between her and Hanna who would often feel compelled to defend her little sisters. Though she loves her parents and elder brothers dearly she feels the strongest connect to her mother and sisters.

HEr brothers would often make fun of Kassandra which would often provoke Hanna and thus spark another fuew with her father. Theyoften did these deliberatly for though they realised it was Hanna who wa responsible for the new found fame and found of the business they have always feared that she would be the one to inherit the business and not them.  They need not have worried though for despite her remarkable skill with cooking and reciped Hanna did long for something besides the day to day drugery of cooking and running a kitchen. She did not know that she was one of the blessed, one of the lucky few what had the spark inborn waiting to be discovered.

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Telen
`7Subj`6:`7 rp

Telen is convinced he has Termiane's attention before speaking.  He has thought a while on how to say a few things, and now that he has to actually speak a few words in a fairly sensible manner, he cannot recall how he had thought to say them.  No matter.  He will sound like an idiot, and no one will be surprised, least of all himself.  "I had, no I was -" he says and there is a pause where he collects thoughts.  "When I was sick for those weeks, many of the nights, someone was in my room.  I know Renlor stayed there often, and he told me Rhyse was there once, and others visited.  So I survived, and somehow, Renlor did too.  I don't think well when I wake, and when I first took a room at the White Stag, I had to repair the room so often I was told I could either pay more or move out.  I believe about that time, you hired me.  Maybe exactly that time.  So I stayed there.  I am coming to the reason I am mentioning all of this."  Distaste has invaded the neutral expression he maintains when amicability falls flat.

Telen continues, "The brawl in the White Stag either woke me, or I started it, but I recall entering a quiet common room, and trying to stay awake, and then waking and looking for something with an edge to throw.  I did not find anything so I threw the table.  Lifted and kicked it, meaning to hit the fellow in front of me and for no reason.  Since I stopped drinking," and other things, "every morning I would wake up trying for violence, some times worse than others.  I would bar my door from the inside, and that seemed to work well enough."  'Well enough' has the same kind subtle irony in it as 'May the Creator shelter you'.  Like a tar patch on a bucket of coals, or a block of ice set out in the sun to weight a stack of hides.  Sure, that, kind of works.  "On a trip overland, I figured I would be traveling alone and if I tried to put my knife through a tree, well, it might delay me a bit getting it out again, but no great harm done."

I will control the violence waking, but there is a trade:  I am hard to wake until some hours have passed.  A bit of paste for your face hardly seems worth complaining about, I cannot believe I did it.  The comment gathers weariness and discards it for self-recrimination.  "I can show you how to wake me, but still, there is that, that it might have to be done."  He remembers now he had suggestions on how this might be less of a problem.  They sound incredibly dumb to him now, in retrospect.  It is only what he did in his travel from Arafel to Caemlyn.  Yes, incredibly dumb.  He is lucky he didn't break his neck falling out of a tree.  "If you would like me to find my own way to Bandar Eban, I will do that.  If I am going with you, I need to show you, and the lady Duriel, some few things before we arrive."  Though not necessarily before they leave.  Would be good though.
OOC.. probably best if the RP takes him solo into the west.  I don't want to hold up RP, either, for folks who are on most of the time.

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Telen
`7Subj`6:`7 travel and RP

Hey there.  If you want to NPC something meantime, cool.  If not, I can add another short section to this.  Route -overland to Illian, by sea to the west coast.  Guess the borderlander will be learning to sail.

(Description after several weeks of travel:  At his hip is a single straight sword sheathed in a hard scabbard, and directly behind it hangs a long knife with a similarly styled -plain and darkly wrapped-- grip.  Fitted clothing on the moderately tall man makes for a relatively slim silhouette.  His boots are soft-soled and his head is shaved, his eyebrows and lashes bleached a bronze gold by the sun, though it could be assumed the original color was much darker.  His grey eyes have a variegated concentration of color near the rim of the iris that is midnight blue, and charcoal outlines a center of ice.  He is deeply tanned over every inch of exposed skin, and his large hands are calloused with a fine network of odd scarring across the backs.  Determination compresses the set of his mouth and jaw when he is not paying mind to keeping his face impassive.  Heat and cold appear to bother him not at all.)

In a small town south of Caemlyn, between Caemlyn and Illian in a more or less direct route, Telen settles in his rented room and pulls off his shirt to examine his back and shoulders.  The faint ruddiness of sunburn has faded to dull tan, but he removes a jar of oil from one of the few tins he has squirreled, pours a bit out into his palm and rubs it into his skin so that, he hopes, the skin will darken and not peel.  Daily baths are part of his past life, and so with nothing to deliberately remove what he applies, he preserves his scant stores.  If he makes no friends, well, it is a small thing.  He wants none here.

He removes his hat and his braids flop down from their confinement about his skull to fall over his shoulders.  Wasting no time, and thinking nothing of it, he unbinds the ends and unbraids the hair.  It does not have much color in it to his mind.  Like sodden, earthy straw.  He supposes one might call it a medium brown, though the color is odd, he thinks there might be shades of green in it.  Grimacing, he slips his knife from its sheathe at his belt and gathers his hair at the nape of his neck, twists it, places the edge of the knife against the thick column, the spine at his neck, and saws outward.  The hairs part easily but the process takes much longer than he expects.  Loose hair falls forward slowly in a fan, tickling skin.

Hours later, after supper when the evening stretches shadows out from every corner, Telen makes use of a mirror at the end of the upstairs hall of the inn before going into his room.  It is a small mirror, and the frame looks as though it has been secured well to the wood paneled wall.  The silver reflects his image back to him half draped in shadow, but he stares at it, repressing an urge to look behind him.  It isn't Telen, which is good.  The man staring back at him has shoulder length curling hair of some medium color.  It could be dark blond.  His eyes appear pale also, even in the poor lighting.  His skin has an obviously new tan, but he hardly notices such things.  The hair is an unruly mane and he runs both hands through it, bewilderment in wide eyes.  His uneven trimming is hidden by a mass of curl.  Where it all came from, he has no idea.  It was straight before he cut it, and it was straight when he looked at it after he cut it.  It must go.  The bloody mirror shows a fair likeness of a Light-stricken fool poet.  Either that or a child in a man's body.

What is left of his hair in the morning is tucked into his hat, which is short brimmed and of thick leather, black as pitch like the rest of his clothing.  He is not sure what he will do with the clippings.  Leave it in the forest maybe for birds and mice to scavenge for nests.  It felt strange coiled in his hands, like a small, sleek furred animal, warming quickly within his hold.  Hard to describe how he felt without hair that, unbraided, hung below his waist, except lighter somehow.  Somehow being different than literally, lighter, and less impeded with movement of his head and neck.  The town must have a barber or seamstress who would shave his head.  Or he could -his thoughts stumble and halt.  Telen is dead.  What does it matter how he behaves? So long as the goal is served.  As when he said it in Caemlyn, something in him dies a little more.
`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Telen
`7Subj`6:`7 travel and RP

Hey there.  If you want to NPC something meantime, cool.  If not, I can add another short section to this.  Route -overland to Illian, by sea to the west coast.  Guess the borderlander will be learning to sail.

(Description after several weeks of travel:  At his hip is a single straight sword sheathed in a hard scabbard, and directly behind it hangs a long knife with a similarly styled -plain and darkly wrapped-- grip.  Fitted clothing on the moderately tall man makes for a relatively slim silhouette.  His boots are soft-soled and his head is shaved, his eyebrows and lashes bleached a bronze gold by the sun, though it could be assumed the original color was much darker.  His grey eyes have a variegated concentration of color near the rim of the iris that is midnight blue, and charcoal outlines a center of ice.  He is deeply tanned over every inch of exposed skin, and his large hands are calloused with a fine network of odd scarring across the backs.  Determination compresses the set of his mouth and jaw when he is not paying mind to keeping his face impassive.  Heat and cold appear to bother him not at all.)

In a small town south of Caemlyn, between Caemlyn and Illian in a more or less direct route, Telen settles in his rented room and pulls off his shirt to examine his back and shoulders.  The faint ruddiness of sunburn has faded to dull tan, but he removes a jar of oil from one of the few tins he has squirreled, pours a bit out into his palm and rubs it into his skin so that, he hopes, the skin will darken and not peel.  Daily baths are part of his past life, and so with nothing to deliberately remove what he applies, he preserves his scant stores.  If he makes no friends, well, it is a small thing.  He wants none here.

He removes his hat and his braids flop down from their confinement about his skull to fall over his shoulders.  Wasting no time, and thinking nothing of it, he unbinds the ends and unbraids the hair.  It does not have much color in it to his mind.  Like sodden, earthy straw.  He supposes one might call it a medium brown, though the color is odd, he thinks there might be shades of green in it.  Grimacing, he slips his knife from its sheathe at his belt and gathers his hair at the nape of his neck, twists it, places the edge of the knife against the thick column, the spine at his neck, and saws outward.  The hairs part easily but the process takes much longer than he expects.  Loose hair falls forward slowly in a fan, tickling skin.

Hours later, after supper when the evening stretches shadows out from every corner, Telen makes use of a mirror at the end of the upstairs hall of the inn before going into his room.  It is a small mirror, and the frame looks as though it has been secured well to the wood paneled wall.  The silver reflects his image back to him half draped in shadow, but he stares at it, repressing an urge to look behind him.  It isn't Telen, which is good.  The man staring back at him has shoulder length curling hair of some medium color.  It could be dark blond.  His eyes appear pale also, even in the poor lighting.  His skin has an obviously new tan, but he hardly notices such things.  The hair is an unruly mane and he runs both hands through it, bewilderment in wide eyes.  His uneven trimming is hidden by a mass of curl.  Where it all came from, he has no idea.  It was straight before he cut it, and it was straight when he looked at it after he cut it.  It must go.  The bloody mirror shows a fair likeness of a Light-stricken fool poet.  Either that or a child in a man's body.

What is left of his hair in the morning is tucked into his hat, which is short brimmed and of thick leather, black as pitch like the rest of his clothing.  He is not sure what he will do with the clippings.  Leave it in the forest maybe for birds and mice to scavenge for nests.  It felt strange coiled in his hands, like a small, sleek furred animal, warming quickly within his hold.  Hard to describe how he felt without hair that, unbraided, hung below his waist, except lighter somehow.  Somehow being different than literally, lighter, and less impeded with movement of his head and neck.  The town must have a barber or seamstress who would shave his head.  Or he could -his thoughts stumble and halt.  Telen is dead.  What does it matter how he behaves? So long as the goal is served.  As when he said it in Caemlyn, something in him dies a little more.

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Telen
`7Subj`6:`7 rp travel

He sits straight in a ladder back chair with a clean but much stained cloth draped over his bare shoulders.  A handled razor glides over the top of his head gripped securely in the steady hand of a middle aged woman.  Clumps of curling hair slide down his forehead and he blinks and exhales through his nose to ease the tickle and irritation without moving his hands or head.  He has been asked twice to be still, the second time with a vague comment on scarring, and that scars often prevent growth of hair, if he should ever want to grow a full head of hair again.  The razor is dipped and a hand passes over the top of his head as if making way for the blade that follows.

Telen wonders, as he always does, if every man feels that vulnerability of the razor passing the raised veins in one's neck, knowing the blade's edge would cut effortlessly and, as is intended, has been.  He has not found complete trust in any man yet.  Perhaps because he knows how easy it is to betray trust for hidden circumstance.  Things that compromise lurking beneath the skin, untold and maybe unknown, sometimes desperately concealed.  Trust is a fragile thing, and he has found too many ways to gainsay it.  A silvered glass is suddenly in front of his solemn stare, and it takes him a moment to understand why the image staring back at him is so strange.  It is not the lack of hair, it is the lack of color where his hairline begins, where his new tan ends.  The pallor of unearthed grubs on one side of a nearly perfect meeting of gentle arcs, and on the other the glow of gold rich wheat.

He will need to cover his head in decreasing increments to protect the skin that has apparently not seen the light of day for years and years.  He chuckles and thanks the woman heartily, and the glass is removed with a jerk.  Everything is done so, instead of holding himself rigid to disguise the tremor of his body in pain, he is in constant dramatic movement.  Except, as per special request as now, while seated under the light and deft touch of a razor encouraged by coin and perhaps his attitude.  "It is done? I thank you.  And I will pay you, Eilen, as soon as I shake out my purse."  He moves to stand, the first lean forward slow so she might protest if he was to remain still any longer, and then he is pulling off the stained cloth and shaking it on the already strewn floor.  It looks as though several rabbits, the doe brown velvety ones with seal points, have been sheared and then set free to scatter their shorn fur all across the room.

He receives a narrow glance and the cloth is snatched out of his grasp, which becomes loose to allow its swift retrieval.  "You do no have to fill the air with your scruff, bad enough it will take weeks to clean it out of the floorboards."  The chiding is ignored.  Telen would offer to clean the room spotless and then begin doing it.  He will not.  He smiles what he knows is engagingly and nods, "Twill remind you of me when I'm gone, that cannot be a bad thing."  He is already stepping out of reach of the cloth as it snaps toward him, throwing another cloud of hairs into the still, almost tepid, air.  "Just you be sure to pay what you owe me."  Of course he will.  He does.

After another several days of travel, his life and identity change once more.  Land or sea, the decision is allowed to haunt him for a day only, and then made for him, as it often is, by someone, or Something, more purposeful.

`7From`6:`7 Maelyn
`7Subj`6:`7 Sorry, love
I gotta get to bed. I hope everything is ok with your connection. I'll see you tomorrow.
Or, actually, later today.
Here was my last emote for you.   :)
Maelyn smiles to herself as she turns down the covers, but doesn't respond right away.
She slides between the sheets with a soft sigh and lays on her side, head propped up by her
arm beneath the pillow so she can gaze at him, still with that same soft smile on her lips.
It is only after several minutes have passed and he seems to have finished his own
preparations for bed that she finally speaks, the words barely above a whisper, though that
is loud enough in the silence of the night. "And so are you, in your own way, Katarth. Sleep
well and wake."
*kiss*
Mae

column7: Welcome to the life of a pirate! :P

column1: `7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Kheldon
`7Subj`6:`7 Welcome to the life of a pirate! :P
*huggles*
I used downloaded the episodes to my computer using bittorrent technology.
And then watched the file(s) on VLC Player.
Step by step:
1. Download VLS Player. It can play any videofile. :) http://www.videolan.org/vlc/
2. Download a bittorrent program. The official one is pretty easy to use and understand, http://www.bittorrent.com/download
3. This is the hardest part. Use a torrent tracker site such as www.mininova.org and searh for Drive. Click on the TV Shows tab.
That'll sort out any irrelevant searches. Then find your episode. In your case it's probably episode 3 of season 1.
Make sure the file sizes are ca 350mb (normal for 1 hour shows). Then make sure that the file has a lot of seeders (those sharing)
preferably over a few hundred.
Then you click on that file and then click on "Download this torrent". If you've installed your torrent program, then
you'll automatically be told to open the file using that program. Do it. And then decide where to save the file.
Speed of download depends on your connection and the number of seeders/leechers.
And for other shows/movies/etc...just repeat step 3. :P
Kheldon

`7From`6:`7 Shai'tan
`7Subj`6:`7 Df Updates
Jaiana
-Current assignment: None.
-Last assignment: None, due to timeline changes and Jai's DF status flipflopping.
-Greatest Accomplishment: Not dying? :P Jai's only been a DF for a short RL time,
ICly only about 50 years. She's very good at rumormongering, so chances are, her
greatest thing has something to do with that.
Current Connections: Close friend of Kinje (he's the one that convinced her to go dark),
the rest have either been reset with timeline changes, or they no longer play.
Lasaria
-Current assignment: Making trouble, more or less. HoF is supposed to be targetting
certain people, but they've more or less left the game (Jerod).
-Last assignment: The capture and retrieval of the Hand of Fear, as well as a certain
Aes Sedai (Sabrina/Jezz). The two have been running amok together ever since, though
Sabrina tends to run off without Lasaria and be much more ... obvious ... than Lasaria
prefers.
-Greatest accomplishment: Succeeding at her last assignment and not dying in the process.
-Current Connections: She has connections with Kinje and Turel, neither can really be called
a "friend" but they're both the closest thing she has to a friend. Sabrina is a common
cohort in crime, but their relationship is sort of a love/hate one. (none of Sabrina's
personalities are all that fond of the HoF, but the HoF absolutely adores all of them...
in a very bizzare way... it's amusing.)

`7From`6:`7 Isleen
`7Subj`6:`7 Shadow Stuff
This is going to be fairly simple:
I have no shadow assignment.
I haven't had any shadow assignments.
My greatest accomplishment for the Shadow: Nothing really
in this timeline because Isleen's status has still to be
discussed with a shadow imm.
Isleen has connections to Kinje and Sabrina.  None of
them really know each other's status.  They just know
each other, and are wary around one another, because none
of them know who of them has the most rank in the Shadow. :P
Okay, so let me explain.  I sent in an app for Isleen,
which Lucardo said was okay, and then Shai'tan told me
that most of what I wanted in my background wasn't going
to be allowed, but wouldn't tell me what -would- be okay.
So I kind of just gave up playing Isleen, because it was
a bit discouraging that a.) the Shadow has been so disorganized
and b.) first I was approved, then I wasn't.
So I suppose what I could do is send you my original
background and let you look it over.  Basically, I had
wanted Isleen to be trained by Lanfear.  Maybe have one or
two spiffy weaves.  But apparently that's asking for the
moon, so I suppose I'll have to re-write it. :)
Let me know what I should do.  I really do like this
character, and would like to get her active again.
Isleen's player

`7From`6:`7 Sadren
`7Subj`6:`7 Last emote of our RP..

It is good that you will recommend her. I will do so as well, when the time comes. Sadren brushes her dress down, smoothing a few wrinkles out as she does. "The position is one that I did not have to offer, Narissa, but one that I think is important. Both of our Ajahs value knowledge.. a History concerning the Formation of the Black Tower will be of utmost importance for future generations." Sadren is quiet for a moment, her cold, doe brown eyes, staring at Narissa with indifference. "But it is a position I established, and one that I will be forced to sacrifice for. Nothing will be asked of the Brown Ajah, but much will be asked of me." She blinks, placing a hand on her pregnant belly. "As far as Matylena goes.. It is likely that she will be chosen. And Iam working to have as many Ajahs behind her as possible when the time comes. A unified Tower is more important than anything else, Narissa. You should know this."  [Sadren]

`7From`6:`7 Sadren
`7Subj`6:`7 Linking and a Linker
Can you tell me if I understand what a linker is properly?
I am reading that there is object code (code which has been
compiled) and functions (which perform needed tasks).
If you use functions in your programs, then the linker
takes the object file and combines it with the object
code to create the executable file.
So, it takes the two different portions of your code,
the object and the fucntion, and links them together
so that they work properly, yes?
-Sads

`7From`6:`7 Sadren
`7Subj`6:`7 Building
I think that we should focus on building areas for the areas we
intend to have RP. Right now, our RP is focused in Tar Valon,
Caemlyn, and Seanchan (Tanchico).
We have a Cairhien in, but not much RP happens in that area.
I had an Aiel Waste built, but it is gone. No idea what happened
to it. I think some zones that we should definitely have since
we are getting a fight code in would be the Blight, for very
difficult monsters, the Waste, also for difficult monsters,
and the Shaido Hold in the wetlands, again, for hard monsters to
fight.
I don't really know if we need to have many more zones put in
because we don't have a population to sustain their use. However,
if we get people in certain guilds that would require an area,
I'd have no problem seeing one put in.
What else would you like concerning building? Just let me know what
kind of information you'd like, and I'll find it.
Going to look up EQ stuff right now, but I have to wade through
all of the boards to find it.
-Sads

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Volkare
`7Subj`6:`7 Background for Liahm Dalren
I'm not looking for inclusion of Liahm (my rename for Volkare) in the DD guild (I think
there are too many Asha'man there already), just looking to get approval for the bits
of the background that touch on DD subjects (service with House Tarborwin).
Liahm Dalren was never satisfied with his life. The first child of a minor
Cairhienin merchant, he was trained from a young age to take over his father's
business, and so he spent from age 6 to age 13 drearily behind a desk, learning
to balance ledgers and follow trading trends. His mother, a seamstress by
trade, always told the most amazing stories of adventure and travel, much at
odds with the boring life that Liahm was quickly growing into. His younger
sister had to learn as well, but she wasn't pushed as much as Liahm by their
father. The situation quickly grew to grate on the young boy, and he ran off,
hitching his fortunes to a passing menangerie. Running messages and tending to
props wasn't much more exciting, but at least he was around exciting people,
and constantly moving through new lands.
He lasted four years with the menagerie, and then found himself back in
Cairhien, bored to tears of mucking out stalls and no closer to performing in
any way, shape, or form. By this time, his mother and father were dead (she
grew sick shortly after he fled home, he passed on shortly after she did) and
his sister had been taken away to Tar Valon (the loss of the second child was
what pushed his mother over the edge). With nothing of his family left, Liahm
swore himself to House Tarborwin as a guardsman, sure that this was the way to
glory, adventure, and excitement. And in a way, he was right.
His training progressed rapidly enough, as the young man was used to physical
exertion, and learned quickly, and soon he was a newly minted Guardsman of
House Tarborwin. He served the House for several years, skirmishing against
Andorans and Tairens before he was 20 and the world changed. Aiel poured over
the Dragonwall again. Liahm fought with the rest of his House, doing what he
could to save the city of his birth. The intervention of the Lord Dragon and
his Aiel undoubtedly saved the young Guardsman's life, and Liahm was left to
help his House rebuild in the wake of the war.
Then the Lord Dragon was taken from the very Sun Palace, and Liahm, now a
Squadman, was chosen to accompany Lord Dobraine to succor the Savior of
Cairhien. He fought long and hard, seeing the devastation wrought by women who
could channel. That wrath was surpassed as the sun outshines a candle by the
fury of the black-coated men who arrived and ended the battle. Then and there,
Liahm Dalren decided that he would serve the Lord Dragon whose subjects had
saved him twice now. On the first recruiting trip to Cairhien, the young man
made himself available to the Asha'man, his awe of the black-coated
slaughterers overshadowing his family's particular fear and hatred of male
channelers. Expecting to be shunted aside to train the Legion of the Dragon,
Liahm was surprised and frightened when it was found that he could learn to
channel.
He was taken to the Farm just weeks after the battle of Dumai's Wells, and
there his true training began. Crispness and precision marked the young
Cairhienin's style, although now and then hints of the showmanship learned with
the menagerie showed through. He quickly became a Soldier, and his strength and
ability with the One Power marked him for quick promotion, and he quickly
became a specialist in combating other channelers. It was his loyalty to Mazrim
Taim, however, that gained him the sword pin of a Dedicated, and sent him to
the White Tower in the Raid. He was one of the men who Traveled into the Ajah
Halls, and he spent the entire duration of the Raid subduing recalcitrant Aes
Sedai with all indication of great enjoyment.
Although his sense of adventure chafes at the forced inactivity at the Black
Tower, he trains for the day when the Aes Sedai once more decide that they are
more important than the Asha'man, fully intending to put them back in their
place (beneath the polished boots of the Asha'man, in his mind) when that day
comes. How this belief will change when it becomes apparent that his sister
Kadiana, now an Aes Sedai of the Red Ajah, is at the Black Tower is yet to be
seen.

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Volkare
`7Subj`6:`7 Background for Liahm Dalren
Mostly just using you as a double-check since I'm my own GL, but also getting approval
for non-channeler participation in Dumai's Wells.

Liahm Dalren was never satisfied with his life. The first child of a minor Cairhienin merchant, he was trained from a young age to take over his father's business, and so he spent from age 6 to age 13 drearily behind a desk, learning to balance ledgers and follow trading trends. His mother, a seamstress by trade, always told the most amazing stories of adventure and travel, much at odds with the boring life that Liahm was quickly growing into. His younger sister had to learn as well, but she wasn't pushed as much as Liahm by their father. The situation quickly grew to grate on the young boy, and he ran off, hitching his fortunes to a passing menangerie. Running messages and tending to props wasn't much more exciting, but at least he was around exciting people, and constantly moving through new lands.

He lasted four years with the menagerie, and then found himself back in Cairhien, bored to tears of mucking out stalls and no closer to performing in any way, shape, or form. By this time, his mother and father were dead (she grew sick shortly after he fled home, he passed on shortly after she did) and his sister had been taken away to Tar Valon (the loss of the second child was what pushed his mother over the edge). With nothing of his family left, Liahm swore himself to House Tarborwin as a guardsman, sure that this was the way to glory, adventure, and excitement. And in a way, he was right.

His training progressed rapidly enough, as the young man was used to physical exertion, and learned quickly, and soon he was a newly minted Guardsman of House Tarborwin. He served the House for several years, skirmishing against Andorans and Tairens before he was 20 and the world changed. Aiel poured over the Dragonwall again. Liahm fought with the rest of his House, doing what he could to save the city of his birth. The intervention of the Lord Dragon and his Aiel undoubtedly saved the young Guardsman's life, and Liahm was left to help his House rebuild in the wake of the war.

Then the Lord Dragon was taken from the very Sun Palace, and Liahm, now a Squadman, was chosen to accompany Lord Dobraine to succor the Savior of Cairhien. He fought long and hard, seeing the devastation wrought by women who could channel. That wrath was surpassed as the sun outshines a candle by the fury of the black-coated men who arrived and ended the battle. Then and there, Liahm Dalren decided that he would serve the Lord Dragon whose subjects had saved him twice now. On the first recruiting trip to Cairhien, the young man made himself available to the Asha'man, his awe of the black-coated slaughterers overshadowing his family's particular fear and hatred of male channelers. Expecting to be shunted aside to train the Legion of the Dragon, Liahm was surprised and frightened when it was found that he could learn to channel.

He was taken to the Farm just weeks after the battle of Dumai's Wells, and there his true training began. Crispness and precision marked the young Cairhienin's style, although now and then hints of the showmanship learned with the menagerie showed through. He quickly became a Soldier, and his strength and ability with the One Power marked him for quick promotion, and he quickly became a specialist in combating other channelers. It was his loyalty to Mazrim Taim, however, that gained him the sword pin of a Dedicated, and sent him to the White Tower in the Raid. He was one of the men who Traveled into the Ajah Halls, and he spent the entire duration of the Raid subduing recalcitrant Aes Sedai with all indication of great enjoyment.

Although his sense of adventure chafes at the forced inactivity at the Black Tower, he trains for the day when the Aes Sedai once more decide that they are more important than the Asha'man, fully intending to put them back in their place (beneath the polished boots of the Asha'man, in his mind) when that day comes. How this belief will change when it becomes apparent that his sister Kadiana, now an Aes Sedai of the Red Ajah, is at the Black Tower is yet to be seen.
`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Volkare
`7Subj`6:`7 Background for Liahm Dalren
Mostly just using you as a double-check since I'm my own GL, but also getting approval
for non-channeler participation in Dumai's Wells.

Liahm Dalren was never satisfied with his life. The first child of a minor Cairhienin merchant, he was trained from a young age to take over his father's business, and so he spent from age 6 to age 13 drearily behind a desk, learning to balance ledgers and follow trading trends. His mother, a seamstress by trade, always told the most amazing stories of adventure and travel, much at odds with the boring life that Liahm was quickly growing into. His younger sister had to learn as well, but she wasn't pushed as much as Liahm by their father. The situation quickly grew to grate on the young boy, and he ran off, hitching his fortunes to a passing menangerie. Running messages and tending to props wasn't much more exciting, but at least he was around exciting people, and constantly moving through new lands.

He lasted four years with the menagerie, and then found himself back in Cairhien, bored to tears of mucking out stalls and no closer to performing in any way, shape, or form. By this time, his mother and father were dead (she grew sick shortly after he fled home, he passed on shortly after she did) and his sister had been taken away to Tar Valon (the loss of the second child was what pushed his mother over the edge). With nothing of his family left, Liahm swore himself to House Tarborwin as a guardsman, sure that this was the way to glory, adventure, and excitement. And in a way, he was right.

His training progressed rapidly enough, as the young man was used to physical exertion, and learned quickly, and soon he was a newly minted Guardsman of House Tarborwin. He served the House for several years, skirmishing against Andorans and Tairens before he was 20 and the world changed. Aiel poured over the Dragonwall again. Liahm fought with the rest of his House, doing what he could to save the city of his birth. The intervention of the Lord Dragon and his Aiel undoubtedly saved the young Guardsman's life, and Liahm was left to help his House rebuild in the wake of the war.

Then the Lord Dragon was taken from the very Sun Palace, and Liahm, now a Squadman, was chosen to accompany Lord Dobraine to succor the Savior of Cairhien. He fought long and hard, seeing the devastation wrought by women who could channel. That wrath was surpassed as the sun outshines a candle by the fury of the black-coated men who arrived and ended the battle. Then and there, Liahm Dalren decided that he would serve the Lord Dragon whose subjects had saved him twice now. On the first recruiting trip to Cairhien, the young man made himself available to the Asha'man, his awe of the black-coated slaughterers overshadowing his family's particular fear and hatred of male channelers. Expecting to be shunted aside to train the Legion of the Dragon, Liahm was surprised and frightened when it was found that he could learn to channel.

He was taken to the Farm just weeks after the battle of Dumai's Wells, and there his true training began. Crispness and precision marked the young Cairhienin's style, although now and then hints of the showmanship learned with the menagerie showed through. He quickly became a Soldier, and his strength and ability with the One Power marked him for quick promotion, and he quickly became a specialist in combating other channelers. It was his loyalty to Mazrim Taim, however, that gained him the sword pin of a Dedicated, and sent him to the White Tower in the Raid. He was one of the men who Traveled into the Ajah Halls, and he spent the entire duration of the Raid subduing recalcitrant Aes Sedai with all indication of great enjoyment.

Although his sense of adventure chafes at the forced inactivity at the Black Tower, he trains for the day when the Aes Sedai once more decide that they are more important than the Asha'man, fully intending to put them back in their place (beneath the polished boots of the Asha'man, in his mind) when that day comes. How this belief will change when it becomes apparent that his sister Kadiana, now an Aes Sedai of the Red Ajah, is at the Black Tower is yet to be seen.

`7From`6:`7 Sadren
`7Subj`6:`7 The new MiT mudconnector description.
Hey guys,
I updated the MudConnector desc a bit. Not much, just a few lines.
Any other coments or ideas before I go and repost this? Anything
I can add to make it better?
-Sads
A Moment in Tyme (MiT) is one of the oldest Wheel of Time
based Muds on the Internet.  Since 1994, our coders and
builders have been working hard to bring in unique new
features and our own original areas.  MiT is currently on
our third major revision of the codebase, and our areas
are all completely original.  At A Moment in Tyme, we have
a dedicated playerbase and an excellent, committed staff of
Immortals.  We have unique systems in place to rank
players' mastery in swordplay and channeling (Wheel of
Time's magic system).
A Moment in Tyme is set on a Timeline that is based on the
first six books. After that, though, Tyme has broken away
to become a mirror world of those books. The Bowl of the Winds
has been found and used, breaking the long winter. Elayne
has returned to Andor and taken the Throne. After the death
of Queen Analinde Su Riaten Rie, Lord Dobraine of House
Taborwin acts as Cairhien's Regent.
The White Tower split pit Sister versus Sister, but an attack
from the Black Tower resulted in Elaida's kidnapping and
subsequent desposing. Now, the White Tower stands united
against the coming of Tarmon Gaidon, with Matylena Taravin
presiding as the new Amyrlin. She has named the Rand al'Thor
as the Dragon Reborn, and there is talk of cleansing the Taint.
And the Seanchan? Tarabon, Arad Doman, and Altara are
all victims of the Ever Victorious Army. The High Lady
Suroth invaded, and conquered Murandy, instead of reaching
into Amadicia. Because of this, High Lady Ilorin Shayndel
Paendrag, fourth in line for the Crystal Throne, has
officially settled into the Panarch's Palace and taken
control of the Hailene. Who will stop them? Word is that
a mercenary group called the Heron Company is being raised
to retake Arad Doman...
A Moment in Tyme is a RP-intensive MUD that features over
twenty guilds. On this MUD, experience is received
exclusively for roleplaying based on emotes. Combat code
is currently being remodified and rebuilt from the ground
up, and will offer a system based on 50 different body
parts as well as have very realistically coded forms with
special procedures.

`7From`6:`7 Duren
`7Subj`6:`7 Re: turn info
The combat code you currently see is not what we're working on.  It was someone
elses failed attempt to build a turn based combat system.  However it lacks
all of the basic features of our new system.  The whole grid system is going away
also, because it prevents combat use with mobs.
Don't hesitate to let us know about any other MUD features that are not accessible,
and if you're around when we open the new code for beta testing, be sure to sign up
and test it out for us.  :)
-Duren

`7From`6:`7 Dawynn
`7Subj`6:`7 Asha'man
A slender young man with a set of slightly narrowed light brown eyes framed in a smooth, almost silky face were it not for a slight tan. Clean cheeks meet a
slim nose, all set above an oval shaped jaw.
Background
Dawynn staggered to his knees, head ringing and blood trickling down his temples. Not his blood, was it? His eyes darted around the tent, colorful spots
blinking in and out of his vision. A painting hung from the southern entrance, depicting a disproportionaly large man in the lookout post of a small vessel,
floating in the sky with a hand pointing towards something afront, in the distance. Ironically, the man's head had been pierced by a stray piece of wood. The
room was covered in dirt and... and blood. A gaping hole in the tent wall revealed the street and the burning tents across.
Alarming shouts and the sound of thunder and ringing of steel foreshadowed the sight that was about to meet Dawynn. Flinching, he stood up and covered the
five paces of ground that lead out to the large, gaping hole and the street. The large pool of smeared blood that lead to the street looked as if someone had
crawled or been dragged across, out of the hole into chaos while bleeding profously. His eyes darted across the ground outside the tents in the Shaido camp
and he saw men lying about, groaning in pain at the loss of limbs or holes torn up by the ball of flame that had hid the tent. He winced, seeing his uncle
lying with stumps where there had been legs, clothes charred and turning into ashes.
He did not have time to mourn. He needed to run, right this instant. He
tossed away the white garnments of gai'shain and scurried about, looking for clothes. He would not be made an Aiel slave again.
Dawynn is a Tar Valoner orphan who grew up in the care of his uncle, Hamin. His uncle was a merchant of sorts, serving as a middle-man, or as he himself
preferred to call it, 'the vital link between the interest and the interested'. In his company, he grew up on the roads, travelling along the trade-routes by
road from Cairhien in the east to Arad Doman in the East. He had seen a lot of interesting things in the world but never quite felt at ease not having a
home. At one point, when he was 12, they stayed in Tar Valon for more than two years, which was the longest
he had ever stayed in a single place. His uncle
took good care of him, as well as he could considering he was not very wealthy and could not settle down in a place long enough. His bargain with two
merchants from Two Rivers who would sell him their acquired tobacco in Tar Valon ensured that he could stay in Tar Valon for those two years, finally
granting Dawynn and opportunity to sleep under the same roof.
The boy though, never felt that being sedentary granted him any special sense of belonging. His home was simply someplace else, with someone else, and he
never found himself being like the next person. He always had questions, as if there should be more to life than existing, that in these times, turning
increasingly menacing every year, there was some place out there where he could do something extraordinary. On their way from Malden, the town was overtaken
by Shaido and him and his uncle were forced to become gai'shain. Not long after, the Shaido suffered a terrible defeat and Dawynn fled along with others,
making his way to Lugard, where he is at present.
(Hoping to be picked up by a recruiting crew of Asha'man)

I wanted to check how likely you both thought it would be for
Brienne to have met Kanya when she was helping out in the
Healing Halls, and if you think that's likely, whether or not
you think that Brienne (with her excessive network of gossip-

this could probably help out a Quest that's been sputtering

ways around it if need be.
Brienne

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Bakur
`7Subj`6:`7 Background - Bakur Ardal
Description
A short man maybe five feet seven inches tall with dark hair and eyes stands here.
He is a stocky man with a nice build, by his looks you may say he is in his late twenties.
He features are fair, delicate, yet handsome. He bears a small scar above his left eye. His
eyes are a deep dark brown and hair deep brown as well almost mistaken for black. His
looks are very normal to say he is of Cairhienin descent, other than the style of his hair
From the looks of him it seems he hasn't had to do much hard work, don't let that fool
you. From the look of his smile and eyes you know how cunning and strong this man
really is.
He wears a silk loose fitting black shirt and dark blue fancy wool trousers. Over
his shirt he wears an black leather vest, starting from the neck of the vest to the
bottom small blue and white strips run across one after the other, covering the
front of it. Over all of this he wears a very nice fitted white wool coat that he keeps
open usually. Ivory cuff-links in the easily recognizable shape of a Rising Sun adorn
his wrists. There is also a well made stitching of a Rising Sun sewn into the left
breast of the coat, made well for good view of the eye. His boots are a highly
polished black leather they come up to just above the ankle. Around his waist is a
polished black leather belt with a white ivory buckle. From the belt hangs three
sheaths one for a sword the other for two daggers. The short sword has a silver handle
with black leather braided in a fancy design around it, the blade is curved and single
fancy design around it, the blade is straight and double edged. The other dagger has a
edged. One dagger has a white ivory handle with black leather braid in another
clear almost crystal handle and double edged curved blade.

his shirt he wears an black leather vest, starting from the neck of the vest to the
bottom small blue and white strips run across one after the other, covering the
front of it. Over all of this he wears a very nice fitted white wool coat that he keeps
open usually. Ivory cuff-links in the easily recognizable shape of a Rising Sun adorn
his wrists. There is also a well made stitching of a Rising Sun sewn into the left
breast of the coat, made well for good view of the eye. His boots are a highly
polished black leather they come up to just above the ankle. Around his waist is a
polished black leather belt with a white ivory buckle. From the belt hangs three
sheaths one for a sword the other for two daggers. The short sword has a silver handle
with black leather braided in a fancy design around it, the blade is curved and single
fancy design around it, the blade is straight and double edged. The other dagger has a
edged. One dagger has a white ivory handle with black leather braid in another
clear almost crystal handle and double edged curved blade.

`7From`6:`7 Bakur
`7Subj`6:`7 Desc - Bakur Ardal
A short man maybe five feet seven inches tall with dark hair and eyes is here.
He is a stocky man with a nice build, by his looks he is in his late twenties.
He features are fair, delicate, yet handsome. He bears a small scar above his left eye. His
eyes are a deep dark brown and hair deep brown as well almost mistaken for black. His
looks are very normal it may be safe to say he is of Cairhienin descent, other than the style of his hair.
He wears a silk loose fitting white shirt and fancy dark blue wool trousers. Over
his shirt he wears an black leather vest. Over all of this he wears a very nice
fitted black wool coat that he keeps open usually. Ivory cuff-links in the easily
recognizable shape of a Rising Sun adorn his wrists. There is also a well made design
of a Rising Sun sewn into the left breast of the coat, made well for good view of the
eye. On his head he wears a well made flat blue velvet hat. His boots are highly
polished black leather they come up to just above the ankle. Around his waist is a
polished black leather belt with a white ivory buckle. From the belt hangs three
sheaths one for a sword the other for two daggers. The short sword has a silver handle
with black leather braided in a fancy design around it, the blade is curved and single
fancy design around it, the blade is straight and double edged. The other dagger has a
edged. One dagger has a white ivory handle with black leather braid in another
fancy design around it, the blade is straight and double edged. The other dagger has a
clear almost crystal handle and double edged curved blade.

Bakur wants to take a trip the Caemlyn to look around and listen, or better yet snoop. He wants to see what other Houses in Andor are up to any tips would serve useful as knowledge. It is mainly just a little vacation to learn new things, meet new faces, or hear news.

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Myrene
`7Subj`6:`7 Myrene BG (Part 2)
With a sense of dread building in her gut, Myrene immediately left
Maradon in the wake of the horsemen. My noon, she was nearly back to
Jambal when the same horsemen appeared in the distance. Hiding low in
the shrubbery along the roadside, she watched as they returned toward
Maradon. The barding and coats of the lighter horses were stained
red. When she arrived back at Jambal sometime after noon, it was to
a scene of horror. Several houses had been burnt to the ground, their
cinders still glowing and smoking. The bodies of several villagers
were lined up at the center of town. They had been slaughtered. The
rest of that day is a misty blur to Myrene: she has never been able to
fully remember what happened next.
What she does know is the outcome of that day and her decisions. Within
the week, the townsfolk had come to blame her for the slaughter of the
townspeople. By stealing back the ice peppers, she had inadvertently
been reported. The innkeeper who had given her the tip had immediately
dispatched a messenger to the Nataraja estate informing them of her
presence. The horsemen had headed west at first light once it was
determined that someone had stolen the ice peppers, and an example was
to be made. However, the townsfolk stood their ground and several of
the House Guard of Nataraja became unruly. A fight had broken out
and the aftermath was what Myrene had stumbled upon.
The townsfolk found Myrene to be the culprit and exiled her from Jambal.
Although her parents pleaded for mercy for their child, the townsfolk
would have nothing of it. Cutting her from brow to cheek, she was marked
as a fugitive and cast out. That day, she learned what it was to truly
be on her own.
Over the course of the next twenty years, she slowly made her way south
from town to town performing simple tasks for those who needed help.
However, she kept out of the sight of most public areas due to her
poorly-healed scar, and was therefore considered something of a hermit
and charlatan. Tales arose over time that she was everything from Aes
Sedai to Shadowspawn. Each time such rumors reached her ears, she would
travel on to the next town before her welcome was worn out. By her
fortieth naming day, Myrene found herself in Salidar. There, she finally
made a name for herself as a seamstress, and the people accepted her
without fear.
Shortly after her fifty-second naming day, the Aes Sedai began to appear.
First, there were no more than a handful. But each day, several more
arrived. Over the course of the next month, it became apparent that
something major had occured within the White Tower. The few residents of
Salidar who hadn't yet fled whispered of a breach within the Aes Sedai,
and that a new Amyrlin was to be chosen. Shortly after the arrival of
the last Aes Sedai, Myrene was taken in as a secretary to a Red Sister
named Demene Tarandrelle. That day, it was discovered that Myrene was
not just a seamstress, but a channeler as well. Under the supervision of
Demene, Myrene Narashdamani became one of the first Novices taken in
by the Rebels, despite her age. In fact, two weeks later, a woman several
decades older, Sharina Malloy, became a Novice as well.
Currently, Myrene Narashdamani is within the Rebel's camp along with the
other Novices recruited during their travels.
(I will fix the beginning of the last mail... in the next one)

`7From`6:`7 Maelyn
`7Subj`6:`7 RE Your bg
Wonderful background, excellent job, I only saw one thing that needs
correcting, and need one clarification. The coorection is - Salidar
was abandoned for 40 years before the AS showed up. They chose it
because it was empty, and so they could gather in relative obscurity.
Myrene can be a seamstress in a town maybe a dozen miles away, and
rumors of a gathering of people in the abandoned town can draw her to
Salidar where she can get the job as secretary,
The clarification is - she is a woman who has the ability to learn, but
will not channel unless taught, correct? How far did she get in her
training with the rebels?
That's it! Let me know and we'll talk about how to make you all
official and stuff.
Mae

`7--] `6A Moment in Tyme MUD Mail System`7 [--
`7From`6:`7 Maelyn
`7Subj`6:`7 More thoughts  :)
`7CC`6: `7Matylena Balinor
Just a quick note - In New Spring (Practice) Moraine is thinking about
the Tower's numbers. There is room for 200 Accepted and 400 Novices
and she knows that there was a time that both Accepted and Novices
bunked two to a room. That isn't done in the books present time
because there is no need. Even with every girl having her own room
there are far more empty rooms than occupied. In Tyme, we have had
the Novices bunk two to a room for some time now, mainly to give
the Novices a 'freind' to rp with when the AS aren't around. It helps
new players feel more connected to the guild. I've tried (not always
successfully) to put less experienced players with more experienced ones
as roomies when I could, also to help the newbies get settled. Then,
when they move to Accepted, they get a private room and it seems like
more of a perk because they no longer have to share and aren't as
cramped. In my mind, Novice beds are slender, cot size things. Two
in a room is crowded, but the Novices are kept too busy to spend much
non-sleeping time there. The Accepted beds are larger, and therefore
feel more luxurious to them, another way of rewarding them for making
it to that level.
Anyway, all that is just to say, even if he had 800 coming here, we
could house them with little effort. It is only the army that concerns
me, and I agree with much of your thinking Maty. Billet them in the
bridge towns and the city. Move them to forts when we can. I think
that would work. And, I also agree that since weevils and rot have
not been a problem in game, food should not be a huge problem. I do
think we will need to increase the supplies coming in, but that should
not be impossible to do. The Tower has stores of food kept fresh with
wards, so we have quite a bit all ready. Increase the trade, and we
should be fine. I don't think it should be a ho-hum whatever kind of
thing, but I don't think it will lead to mass starvation or anything like
he is talking about. Maybe some items will become more scarce or
expensive, but nothing like Great Depression bread lines.
Its too bad we don't have a merchants guild anymore. We could generate
some rp with them and work out trade agreements  :)
Mae
